data.text:
Factsheet

What does the noun parsnip mean?

There are two meanings listed in OED's entry for the noun parsnip. See ‘Meaning & use’ for definitions, usage, and quotation evidence.

How common is the noun parsnip?

About 0.3occurrences per million words in modern written English

17500.3417600.3417700.3717800.5217900.5718000.5418100.5718200.5518300.4618400.4418500.4418600.4218700.4318800.4318900.4619000.4819100.4919200.5119300.4819400.419500.3519600.3219700.2919800.2919900.3120000.3220100.33

How is the noun parsnip pronounced?

British English

PARSS-nip

U.S. English

PARSS-nuhp

Where does the noun parsnip come from?

The earliest known use of the noun parsnip is in the Middle English period (1150—1500).

OED's earliest evidence for parsnip is from around 1390, in Pistel of Swete Susan.

parsnip is of multiple origins. A borrowing from Latin. Perhaps also a borrowing from French.

Etymons: Latin pastināca; French pasnaie.

Nearby entries

Etymology

Summary

Perhaps of multiple origins. A borrowing from Latin. Perhaps also a borrowing from French.

Etymons: Latin pastināca; French pasnaie.

Ultimately < classical Latin pastināca carrot, parsnip (perhaps < pastinum pastine n.; the suffix represents ‑āca, suffix forming nouns, especially names of plants), perhaps via Middle French pasnaie (c1180…

Ultimately < classical Latin pastināca carrot, parsnip (perhaps < pastinum pastine n.; the suffix represents ‑āca, suffix forming nouns, especially names of plants), perhaps via Middle French pasnaie (c1180 in Old French; also pasnaise; French panais; compare also Middle French, French † pastinade (1501), Middle French (Provence) pastenargue (1476)), with the ending remodelled after neep n. (compare turnip n.). The development of the β forms is unexplained.

Notes

The Latin term has been borrowed into other Germanic languages, compare Middle Dutch pastenake (Dutch pastinak), Middle Low German pasternāk, pastināke, Old High German pastinac, pasternaca (Middle High German pasternacke, pasternac, German Pastinake, Pastinak), Old Swedish pastinata, palsternakka (Swedish palsternacka), Danish pastinak (17th cent. as pestenak). Compare also Italian pastinaca (1288), Old Occitan pastenaga parsnip, carrot. The Old English Glossaries render post-classical Latin pastinaca as English feld moru, walhmore, wealmoru, more, etc., 13th cent. walmore, c1400 wolemore. Compare English regional (southern) pasmet, pasmut, passment, U.S. regional pasnet, with alteration of the final syllable.

In other dictionaries

passe-nẹ̄pe, n. in Middle English Dictionary

1.

A plant, Pastinaca sativa var. hortensis (family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae)) , with large pinnate leaves and yellow flowers, widely grown for its cream-coloured, sweet, fleshy root; the root itself, used as a vegetable and for fodder. Also: any other plant of the genus Pastinaca.

The wild form of the parsnip, var. sylvestris, is native to southern and central Europe.

Þe persel, þe passenep, poretes to preue.

Pistel of Swete Susan (Vernon MS.) 107

Euerich herbe wiþ a roote of moche norisshinge haþ seed þat is nought norisshynge, as it fareþ in pasnepis and in rapis.

J. Trevisa, translation of Bartholomaeus Anglicus, De Proprietatibus Rerum (British Library MS. Add.) f. 244v

Also this mone is sowyng of pasnepe.

translation of Palladius, De re Rustica (Duke Humfrey MS.) (1896) ix. 56 (Middle English Dictionary)

Drynke a sponful at onys with watyr dystyllyde of..parsepare.

Practica Phisicalia John of Burgundy in H. Schöffler, Mittelenglischen Medizinliteratur (1919) 237 (Middle English Dictionary)

Parsnepes and carettes.

T. Elyot, Castel of Helthe (new edition) 25

Rotys for a gardyn: Persenepez, Turnepez, .

in A. Amherst, Hist. Gardening in Eng. (1896) 76 (Middle English Dictionary)

A Parsnip, partinaca.

P. Levens, Manipulus Vocabulorum sig. Mi/1

What should I speake of cucumbers, muske melons, pompions, potatoes, parsneps, carrets, turn vps.

Estate of Virginia 13

Eating buttered parsnebbs these 2 last nights.

R. Hooke, Diary 24 November (1935) 330

The Garden-Roots that thrive well in Carolina, are Carrots, Leeks, Parsnips, Turneps.

J. Lawson, New Voyage to Carolina 77

To sow parsneps in the open fields.

Gentleman's Magazine June 261/1

The Parsnip was not so common as heretofore.

W. Bentley, Diary vol. III. 451

The parsnep is a hardy biennial of easy culture.

J. Baxter, Library of Agricultural & Horticultural Knowledge 395

They are especially fond of potatoes, turnips, carrots, beets, onion, parsnips, corn, barley, rye and alfalfa.

Science 21 June 689/2

The carrot and the parsnip each has a wild counterpart belonging to the same species growing in this and other countries.

G. D. H. Bell, Cultivated Plants of Farm i. 3

We had roast parsnips with our beef as well as roast potatoes.

R. Dahl, My Uncle Oswald viii. 86

Pastinaca L.—Parsnips. Somewhat pubescent biennials with strong characteristic smell.

C. Stace, New Flora of British Isles 609

A perennial umbelliferous plant, Sium sisarum, a species of water parsnip, formerly much cultivated in Europe for its esculent tubers; the root of…

A plant, Pastinaca sativa var. hortensis (family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae)), with large pinnate leaves and yellow flowers, widely grown for its…

Scottish and Irish English (southern). A parsnip. Cf. mype, n.

A perennial umbelliferous plant, Sium sisarum, a species of water parsnip, formerly much cultivated in Europe for its esculent tubers; the root of…

A plant, Pastinaca sativa var. hortensis (family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae)), with large pinnate leaves and yellow flowers, widely grown for its…

A parsnip.

Scottish and Irish English (southern). A parsnip. Cf. mype, n.

2.

With distinguishing word: any of various plants of the family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae) allied to or resembling the parsnip.

meadow, wild parsnip, etc.: see the first element. See also cow-parsnip n., water parsnip n.

Staphilinus, wylde parsnyppe.

T. Elyot, Dictionary

Sphondilium..may be called in englishe Cowpersnepe or rough Persnepe.

W. Turner, Names of Herbes sig. G.v

The Sea Parsneppe.

J. Parkinson, Theatrum Botanicum 1286

A Poultis of Wild-Parsnips; Flowers, Leaves, and Stalks.

J. Wesley, Primitive Physick (ed. 5) 38

Thaspium, a genus of North American orthospermous Umbelliferæ... Its popular American name is Meadow Parsnip.

J. Lindley & T. Moore, Treasury of Botany vol. II. 1140

The flies..may be found on the flowers of cow parsnip (Heracleum sphondylium Linn.), and similar Umbelliferous weeds.

K. M. Smith, Textbook of Agricultural Entomology xiii. 229

Among its plants and grasses grows the rare water parsnip.

Trilogy July–August 49/1

Name for various wild umbellifers with finely-divided leaves.

With distinguishing word: any of various plants of the family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae) allied to or resembling the parsnip.

With distinguishing word: any of various plants of other genera of the family Apiaceae, thought to resemble lovage in some way.

Originally: any of various umbelliferous plants used medicinally; esp. the herbaceous plants Laserpitium latifolium, L. siser, Seseli tortuosum, and…

= ass's parsley, n.

Chiefly North American. Any of various North American plants of the family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae), which are thought to resemble European…

†a. Applied by Turner to Carum Bulbocastanum; b. now usually applied to Ptychotis heterophylla (Carum heterophyllum).

(Also asses' parsley) any of several common umbelliferous plants resembling parsley or chervil but unpalatable or poisonous, including cow parsley (A…

Phrases

Also proverbs.

P.1.

Proverb. fine (also fair, soft) words butter no parsnips: see butter v. Phrases P.3.

P.2.

Phrases. Chiefly colloquial and humorous.

P.2.a.

† before you can say parsnips: very rapidly. Cf. before one can (also could) say Jack Robinson at Jack Robinson n. Obsolete. rare.

‘You'll come back again,’ says she, ‘That's what I will; before you can say parsnips, my darling,’ says he.

G. Colman, John Bull ii. ii. 23

P.2.b.

† to look parsnips: to look sour or displeased. Obsolete. rare.

‘I'm delighted,’ said Jack, looking parsnips.

T. Hook, Jack Brag vol. II. iv. 167

P.2.c.

I beg your parsnips: ‘I beg your pardon’.

Parsnip,..I beg ∼s (statt pardon) bitt' um Entschuldigung.

H. Baumann, Londinismen 131/2

Oh, I beg yer parsnips!

W. S. Gilbert, Fairy's Dilemma ii. ii. 35

Who said Christ is good?—I beg your parsnips, says Alf.—Is that a good Christ, says Bob Doran, to take away poor little Willy Dignam?

J. Joyce, Ulysses ii. xii. [Cyclops] 290

At one point in the interview, he actually says, ‘I beg your parsnips?’ when he doesn't quite hear a question.

National Post (Canada) (Nexis) 15 January al3

Frequency

parsnip typically occurs about 0.3 times per million words in modern written English.

parsnip is in frequency band 4, which contains words occurring between 0.1 and 1 times per million words in modern written English. More about OED's frequency bands

Frequency data is computed programmatically, and should be regarded as an estimate.

Frequency of parsnip, n., 1750–2010

* Occurrences per million words in written English

Historical frequency series are derived from Google Books Ngrams (version 2), a data set based on the Google Books corpus of several million books printed in English between 1500 and 2010.

The overall frequency for a given word is calculated by summing frequencies for the main form of the word, any plural or inflected forms, and any major spelling variations.

For sets of homographs (distinct entries that share the same word-form, e.g. mole, n.¹, mole, n.², mole, n.³, etc.), we have estimated the frequency of each homograph entry as a fraction of the total Ngrams frequency for the word-form. This may result in inaccuracies.

Smoothing has been applied to series for lower-frequency words, using a moving-average algorithm. This reduces short-term fluctuations, which may be produced by variability in the content of the Google Books corpus.

Frequency of parsnip, n., 2017–2023

* Occurrences per million words in written English

Modern frequency series are derived from a corpus of 20 billion words, covering the period from 2017 to the present. The corpus is mainly compiled from online news sources, and covers all major varieties of World English.

Smoothing has been applied to series for lower-frequency words, using a moving-average algorithm. This reduces short-term fluctuations, which may be produced by variability in the content of the corpus.

Entry history for parsnip, n.

parsnip, n. was revised in June 2005.

parsnip, n. was last modified in December 2023.

oed.com is a living text, updated every three months. Modifications may include:

further revisions to definitions, pronunciation, etymology, headwords, variant spellings, quotations, and dates;

Revisions and additions of this kind were last incorporated into parsnip, n. in December 2023.
